Bulma is framework agnostic and works everywhere
Bulma has 21 Components, 20 of them are unique â€“ for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
Bulma has light and dark themes
Bulma support more than 2 themes at the same time

Imported JavaScript bundle size (minified) â€“ Bulma does not include any JavaScript by default but all interactivities require custom JavaScript. There's an unofficial @vizuaalog/bulmajs package that provides interactivity, which is 7.4kB.
Bulma does not have any dependencies but all interactivities require custom JavaScript. There's an unofficial @vizuaalog/bulmajs package that provides interactivity.
Bulma CSS file is available on CDN
Bulma provides component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
Bulma does not requires a Node.js environment
Bulma does not provide micro CSS files for each component
Bulma does not use wide-gamut P3 colors by default
Bulma uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
Bulma doesn not use native CSS nesting

<svg viewBox="0 0 1024 1024" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><rect x="256" y="670.72" width="512" height="256" rx="128" fill="#1AD1A5"/><circle cx="512" cy="353.28" r="256" fill="white"/><circle cx="512" cy="353.28" r="261" stroke="black" stroke-opacity="0.2" stroke-width="10"/><circle cx="512" cy="353.28" r="114.688" fill="#FF9903"/></svg>
daisyUI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
daisyUI has 61 components, 57 of them are unique â€“ for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
daisyUI supports unlimited themes at the same time, allowing for dynamic theme switching.
daisyUI doesn't ship JavaScript to browsers
daisyUI has no dependencies. It's immune to 3rd party vulnerabilities, dependency version mismatch, and deprecation issues.
In GitHub's top 400 repositories of all time
daisyUI CSS file is available on CDN
daisyUI provides tokens, root-level CSS variables and component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
daisyUI can be used as a standalone file, with Tailwind CSS standalone version. This is useful for projects without a Node.js environment.
daisyUI provides micro CSS files for each component
daisyUI uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
daisyUI uses native CSS nesting, reducing the CSS file size
Comparing daisyUI and Bulma: What are the main differences?

Thousands of developers have starred daisyUI on GitHub, indicating their trust and interest in the project. Bulma includes essential components. daisyUI's component count is higher than Bulma's. daisyUI keeps things simple for your project by having no dependencies
Bulma includes essential components. daisyUI's component count is higher than Bulma's.
Bulma's theming system works well for many use cases. If you need to change themes dynamically (e.g., for user preference), daisyUI's runtime CSS variable approach makes this easier.
Thousands of developers have starred daisyUI on GitHub, indicating their trust and interest in the project. Bulma is downloaded often. daisyUI is downloaded more frequently each week on NPM
Thousands of developers have starred daisyUI on GitHub, indicating their trust and interest in the project.
Bulma is downloaded often. daisyUI is downloaded more frequently each week on NPM.
daisyUI keeps things simple for your project by having no dependencies.
daisyUI's main goal is to add pre-designed components to Tailwind CSS using class names. This approach differs from Bulma, which is more complicated to use and customizes components.
